titleStmt.title: M110 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M110 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p.
Paginated 26-30. On verso of p. 29, a fragment from Between the Acts, paginated 186.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: Spenser with his eye upon the reader in the great room.
Yet the audience for all its size and compulsion is silent.

l.add: If we cd. measure the effoect of the audience we shd. have a hold upon the play.

p.l: That is one of the deep gulfs that lies between us
and the play. They crowd there; daily; but they neither

priase praise nor blame. We must compare it with our
won own
sielnce silence

at the Russian ballet or the
cima cinema , in their early days.

A new art comes upon us so
surpinsgly surprisingly that we sit
silent , recognising what we cannot measure.
To the Elizabethans the expressive power of words

after their long inadequacy
ust must have been overwhelming.

There at the
Glove Globe or at the Rose men and women whose only

reading had been the Bible or some old
chonicle chronicle came out
into the light of the present moment. They saw themselves

splendidly dressed. They heard
themslves themselves saying out loud
what they had never said yet. They heard their aspirations,

their profanities, their
ribaldires ribaldries spoken out loud by human
voices in poetry.
The play then owes its hyperbole to the audience in the

pennu seats. At their command it is
vio;ent violent ; it xmxmxmmxmx
it is coarse; it is poexxx xmxmxmxm a parody, of actual
facts. like our own detective stories and best sellers

a
paody parody a
trasnformation transformation of actual fact. But in the seats
in the covered part of the house, there were nobles, rulers,

scholars. Their
silenc silence is harder to explain. For they were
redares readers ; they had the Latins and the Greeks at the back
of their minds. How could it have been that the trained

taste of such
speactoars spectators received the extraordinary
illumination of these English plays with no more comment

p.l: The soul that walked between delicate groves keeps to a
narrow path between hedges. While Montaigne ranged the world.
micing mixing garrulously with everyone, and speculating freely,
Bacon kept to the narrow path. Yet even in the shade

his thought is embodied. His deep meditations are given
visibe visible

xxxxx concrete form. "Nay
bretire retire men cannot when they would:

quote.l: of privateness even in age and sickness which require the

Shadow; Like old Townsmen that will still be sitting at
ther their
street door, though thereby they offer Age to scorn."

p.l: Even in the delicate grove thought is coloured.

add.quote: The colours that show shew best by candlelight, are: white, carnation, & a kinde of sea-water green

p.l:
His contempt was
fr for hyperbole; not for the art of speech.
He was teaching the ranting players to speak slowly, closely
subtly. He was proving that there is another kind of poetry,

thepoetry the poetry of prose. He was doing his part to bring the
critic critical share in bringing the shade
faculty into being. prose of the mind He was making an end of anonymity. There by [making?]
